abstracts.cdata!:
The Ketsana Emergency Reconstruction and
            Rehabilitation Project for Cambodia had a satisfactory
            outcome with moderate risk to development outcome, and
            satisfactory performance by both, the Bank and the borrower.
            The lessons learned were: (1) A simple project design based
            on the best available preliminary damage and needs
            assessment facilitated quick processing and start-up of
            implementation. (2) Use of retroactive financing and force
            account by government to get large and almost immediate
            positive impacts and reinforce collaboration with
            government, especially in an emergency operation. (3) Use
            the simpler and quicker Single Source Selection (SSS) for
            appointing key consultants for emergency operations in
            countries with weak technical and institutional capacities.
            (4) During the implementation stage, target local
            contractors with simple measures to ensure better quality
            construction. (5) If community participation during project
            preparation is impossible for an emergency operation,
            conduct information sessions and outreach campaigns as early
            as possible during implementation. (6) Include public road
            safety awareness programs and campaigns, even for rural road
            construction projects. (7) Consider applying bitumen seals
            for dust control on laterite or gravel roads through rural settlements.
